content.text: Measure the vertical distance \(d_0\), in mm, between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench
On Fig. 1.1, mark clearly the distance you have measured
Hang a 1.0N load on the spring. Record the value of the load \(L\) in Table 1.1. Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(d\) between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = (d_0 - d)\). Record the value of \(e\) in the table
Repeat steps (iii) and (iv) using loads of 2.0N, 3.0N, 4.0N and 5.0N. Record all the readings and results in the table
L/N
Fig. 1.1
Plot a graph of \(e / \text{mm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(L / \text{N}\) (\(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. The spring has been set up for you. Do not change its position
Measure and record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into the measuring cylinder. Transfer the water from the measuring cylinder to the beaker
Place the thermometer in the beaker of water
Measure and record in the table the temperature of the water at 30 s intervals until you have a total of six values up to time \(t = 150 \text{s}\)
Empty the beaker. Repeat step **(b)** using \(250 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
volume of water
State whether the rate of cooling is significantly faster, slower, or about the same when using the larger volume. Justify your answer by reference to your readings
statement
justification
If this experiment were to be repeated in order to check the results, it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two such conditions that should be controlled
In this experiment, you will investigate the rate of cooling of water
You are provided with a supply of hot water. Carry out the following instructions, referring Fig. 2.1
Draw a circuit diagram of the circuit set up for you, using standard symbols
Switch on. Measure and record the current \(I_{\mathrm{A}}\), and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{L}\). Switch off
Disconnect the voltmeter and reconnect it across lamp \(\mathbf{M}\). Switch on
Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{M}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{M}\). Switch off
Calculate the potential difference across both lamps using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = V_{\mathrm{L}} + V_{\mathrm{M}}\)
Calculate the combined resistance \(R_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the three lamps using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{A}}}{I_{\mathrm{A}}}\)
Switch on. By connecting the voltmeter suitably each time, measure and record the potential difference across each lamp in turn. Switch off
Calculate the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) across the three lamps using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{\mathrm{L}} + V_{\mathrm{M}} + V_{\mathrm{N}}\)
Rearrange the circuit so that the three lamps are in **series** with each other
A student suggests that \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) should be equal to \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\)
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
In this experiment, you will investigate the potential differences across circuit comp
The circuit is set up for you
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied
block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw the outline of the block
Remove the block and draw a normal at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{E}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\) to the left of the normal and at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 4.1
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on the line \(\mathbf{FE}\), placing one pin close to \(\mathbf{E}\). Mark the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\)

Replace the block and observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block, so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other. Mark the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Remove the block
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) and label this point \(\mathbf{G}\)
Draw the line \(\mathbf{GE}\)
Calculate the ratio \(\frac{i}{r}\)
(j) Repeat steps (c) – (i) but with the angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\)
r =
(k) A student suggests that the ratio \(\frac{i}{r}\) should be a constant. State and explain briefly whether your results support this suggestion
**Tie your ray trace into this Booklet between pages 10 and 11.**
Measure and record the angle of refraction \(r\) between the line \(\mathbf{GE}\) and the normal
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light passing through a transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
